The law is intended for cases in which doubt may arise. Itis to be interpreted on this basis (Bk. I, Ch. 1).

A legal enemy is not like a fugitive from justice (Bk. Ι, Chr).

The law governing pirates and wild beasts is not applicable to enemies, i.e., there are laws ol war (Bk. I, Ch. 4).

A usage does not admit extension in the matter ol place, persons, situations, or time (Bk. Ι, Ch. 4).

War is not a hunt. Political territory is something more than a private domain (Bk. Ι, Ch. 5).

The immunity oi a church is opposed to the public interest andro the common law (Bk. Ι, Ch. 5).

A neutral is called upon to hand over the spoils oi war to the victor only aiter a complete victory (Bk. Ι, Ch. 5).

The jurisdiction oi a church differs lrorn that ol a prince, because to be exempt irom local jurisdiction is not the same as to be outside a territory (Bk. Ι, Ch. 5).

The doctrine of continuous stealing is based on the fact that not only the seizure of the property of another but also the retention of it is an act oi theit (Bk. Ι, Ch. ὁ).

The case of a man who llees to a church and ol a man being forcibly taken through itare identical (Bk. Ι, Ch. 7).

“Whatever stands in the original is implied in full in the citation” (Bk. Ι, Ch. 7).

“The dicta oi learned men should be interpreted in accordance with the laws and the authorities which they have cited '' (Bk. Ι, Ch. 7).
